I have the honor to report that the Indian Day school at Whitefish Lake is in need of a new heating stove. The one in use is worn out and absolutely dangerous. Mr. Separate School Inspector Jones states that a teacher's desk is required for the Whitefish Lake school, and I have to request that you will be good enough to ascertain the cost of a suitable desk and advise the Department. Indian Office, Manitowaning, Ont.
20th August 1909-

Sir,

Referring to Official letter of date 30th Ult., informing me that Mr Inspector Jones states that a teacher's desk is required for the Whitefish Lake School and instructing me to ascertain the cost of a suitable desk.

I have the honor to report that there is a very good desk at the old Buswah School that could be sent to the teacher from here. This school has been closed for some time and I have given instructions to an Indian to remove the desk and stove over to Manitowaning where I will store them in the Agency barn until required. The old building is in a very dilapidated condition and the stove and desk in any event are better out of it as it simply impossible to keep it closed. I will have to pay $1.50 for having the stove and desk brought over, but I consider it money well spent. If you think well of my proposition, to send the desk to the teacher at Whitefish Lake I can have it crated at a cost of about $1, and this will save the expense of buying a new desk.

The gloves and cap you mention should be sent to Whitefish station to the address of the teacher and the express or freight prepaid.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 24, 1909.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th inst., and in reply I beg to say that the Department approves of your action in having the teacher's desk and the stove removed from the old Bunwah school and you may, as suggested, send the desk to the Whitefish Lake school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

C.L.D. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

284---19 Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith a letter addressed to you from the Rev. Jos. Specht in reference to the Whitefish Lake school and in regard to his statement that the school house needs repairs from top to bottom so I have the honor to report as follows. I visited this school within the last week and found that the building is not in such a deplorable condition as the letter of Father Specht would lead one to believe; true, the building is an old one built of logs but it is quite habitable and I cannot see how any extensive improvements could be done to it as I consider that this would be only wasting money. The floors in the school and teachers quarters are not as good as they might be and the walls of the dwelling require re-papering and the walls of the school treated to a coat of whitewash.

It is not the condition of the school or dwelling that makes it difficult to get a teacher for this school but its environment, as the school is situated in a very lonely place. I think if there were new floors put in the school and dwelling, the walls of dwelling re-papered and the school room whitewashed that this is all that should be done at the present time as it would be much better to build a new school than to put out any extensive improvements on the old log building.

In February, last, the Department called for tenders for the erection of a combined school-house and teacher's residence at Whitefish Lake. Two tenders were received, one from Mr. Evans of Sudbury for $4000.00 and one from Mr. Joseph Lalonde of St. Andrew's East, Que., for $3850.00. Mr. Lalonde's tender was conditional on his receiving the contract for the Golden Lake School, but he did not receive this and of course his tender for Whitefish Lake could not be considered. Mr. Evans's tender was considered too high at the time as Mr. Ghene's estimate of the cost was only $3200.00.

In April the Department, after making some changes in the specifications, which if they would not lower the price would make it more convenient to get the work done, again
again called for tenders. The result was that only one was received from Mr. Evans and his price this time was $4500.00, $500.00 more than the first time. This, he stated, was due to an increase in the cost of material and labour and the difficulty in getting in the material when the ice had gone.

About the time these tenders were due Mr. F. A. Booth, carpenter and builder of Ottawa, saw the advertisement and called at the Department. At your direction he was given a set of the plans and specifications and he now submits an offer to erect the building for $4364.28; or, if spruce v joint be substituted for plaster on the walls, for $4513.28. Mr. Chene's estimate of the cost of this work was based upon the assumption that material would only have to be drawn four miles, but the Department understands that it has to be teamed from Sudbury, a distance of 15 miles, and a portion of the road, that on the reserve, is very bad; in fact it is so bad that it will necessitate doubling teams to take in a load of material of any size. In view of this fact it may be that Mr. Booth's offer is a reasonable one!

The undersigned has the honour to report that, it being necessary to erect a combined school-house and teacher's residence on the Whitefish Lake reserve, on Georgian Bay, in the province of Ontario, tenders were called for in February, 1912. Two tenders were received, one from H. D. Evans, of Sudbury, for $4,000.00, and one from J. Lalonde, of Andrews Pant, P.Q., for $3,850.00.

Mr. Lalonde's tender was conditional on his receiving the contract for another school-house (the Golden Lake) which was being otherwise disposed of, and his tender for Whitefish Lake school could not therefore be considered. Mr. Evans's tender was considered to be too high at the time, as the estimate of the engineer employed by the Department amounted to only $3,800.00.

In April, 1912, the Department, after making some changes in the specifications which, if they would not lower the cost, would make it more convenient to get the work done, again called for tenders. The result was that only one was received - from Mr. Evans, and his price this time was $4,500.00 - $500.00 more than his previous tender. This, he stated, was due to an increase in the cost of materi-
and labour and the difficulty in getting in the material when the ice had gone.

About the time when these tenders were due, Mr. F. A. Booth, carpenter and builder of Ottawa, saw the advertisement and called at the Department and was given a set of the plans and specifications; and he now submits an offer to erect the building for $4,364.88, or, if sprung v joint be substituted for planter on the walls, for $4,315.88.

The estimate, above mentioned, of the engineer employed by the Department, was based upon the assumption that material would have to be drawn only four miles; but the Department understands that it has to be hauled from Sudbury, a distance of fifteen miles, and a portion of the road - that on the reserve - is very bad; in fact it is so bad that it will necessitate doubling teams in order to take in a load of material of any size.

A resolution has been passed by the Whitefish Lake band in favour of the cost of the building being charged to their capital.

In view of the circumstances above mentioned, the undersigned would recommend that the offer of Mr. Booth to erect the building referred to for $4,315.88 be accepted and that the cost be charged, under section 90 of the Indian Act - as the work when completed will be in the nature of a permanent improvement - to the capital at the credit of the Whitefish Lake band, which amounts to $46,668.88.

Mr. Conley of this Department, who has recently returned from Whitefish Lake, reports that there is no necessity for the erection of a new school building there if the present one is properly repaired. Sir:—

In reply to Official Letter No. 151715/5 of July 31st, last, I have the honor to report that I have consulted different contractors, and men capable of doing the work of repairs at Whitefish Lake School, and none of them are desirous of taking the contract of work, but would go and work by the day. Sir:

Upon raising a loose board in the floor I found two feet of water under the class-room, and some of the sleepers so decayed that they will not hold the nails. No concrete foundation can be seen above the ground, and the sills appear to be still below the surface and are sprung out of place with the frost. I should judge by the hole underneath the class-room that the building has been raised two feet since it was first erected, but no new sleepers or floor were put in.

I might say that this building is situated below the hill on the level with the Whitefish Lake and cannot be drained, the water lies under the school room nine months in each year, which causes it to be very unsanitary. During the winter months the frost heaves the building which breaks the plaster between the logs and twists the doors in such positions that they will not close, therefore the building has to be repaired quite often.

Dear Sir,

Since our school was burned down in May 1917, we have all been extremely anxious to have a new one. During the war we have patiently waited to ask the Department for the necessary funds to erect a suitable building for the education of our dear children.

Now that the war is happily over, we the undersigned members of the Whitefish Lake Band, Interior, come to you with the greatest sincerity and most earnestly supplicate you to build us a school, thereby affording our children an opportunity to receive an education and to make their future education secure everything else, and we are cheerfully ready to make all sacrifices required for this great work.

Memorandum,

Hon. Mr. Neighon,

Application has been made to the Department by the Indians of the Whitefish Lake reserve, Ont., to have a new school and a teacher's residence erected on their reserve. The old building was destroyed by fire in May, 1917, and the school is now being conducted in temporary quarters in the Roman Catholic church.

This band have $61,884.25 to their credit in Capital Fund, and there are between 25 and 30 children of school age on the reserve.

I would ask your authority to expend the requisite amount from the Indians' funds for the erection of a school and a teacher's residence. It is expected that the cost will be approximately $4500.00. Tenders will be asked by public advertisement.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Mr. Agent Lewis encloses a letter addressed to him by the Chief and principal men of the Whitefish Lake Band of Indians requesting the Department to have a new school and teacher's residence erected on their reserve.

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 15718-9 of the 20th instant, in connection with the Department having under consideration the erection of a log school and teacher's residence at the Whitefish Lake Reserve; instead of the frame building on which tenders have recently been called, and it is proposed to have work carried out by the band. In reply I have the honor to report that a log building would be quite suitable for the purpose, and it should be erected more economically than a frame structure.

There is an abundance of logs on the reserve suitable for the work just across the lake from where the proposed school is to be erected.

It is my opinion that the work can be carried out by the Indians, but there will have to be a white man, who is a skilled workman, in charge, in order that the building may be erected in accordance with the plan, and to keep the Indians at work.

A system of contract work would be better than allowing them to erect the walls on, as the slopers not too quickly push the building up banked with earth.

I must say that the only way the Department can have the Indians do this work is to have some white man in charge and pay him a wage by the day to look after the work for as the building is left to the Indians to erect alone, it will never be completed.

July 5th 1919

Dear Sir,

We learn through the Saltege Chamber B. that the Department has suddenly refused to erect on our Reserve the school which was officially promised us last May. We are deeply grieved at this refusal and we beg to protest with the utmost vehemence against this change of mind. At the request of Mr. Agent Lewis we had voluntarily cleared a nice piece of land and were waiting for the contractor to begin the works.

This refusal is very strange indeed. The Department knew very well last May that the materials are costly. Why this change? The government is spending millions and millions to erect Parliament Buildings and other constructions and we are refused a few thousand dollars of our own money to build a decent shelter where our children could receive comfortably a reasonable sum of instruction.

Again; splendid and costly schools and sometimes roads grants have been given to many Reserves and we are denied equal
treatment with others. We have never asked for any grant of any kind, road grants, farm implements etc., the Department has never spent one cent for any school building on our Reserve. The old school was a log building put up by the Indians.

For nearly two years we had no teaching at all. Last year our children were taught in a church too large for a class-room, as Inspector Sinn has declared. It is not all this provoking. Last year we refused joining a General Union of all Indians in Canada to vindicate our rights and obtain justice because we trusted the Department. Now the Department deceives our hopes by not fulfilling its promise. We therefore appeal to you Mr. Scott and beg you to build our school this summer.

Your humble servant,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

CANADA Ottawa, August 4, 1920.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Lewis, Manitowaning, has forwarded a request from the principal men of the Whitefish Lake Band requesting the Department to purchase two buildings situated at the gold mine, about six miles distant, and have them moved to Whitefish Lake Village and re-erect them for use as a school and teacher's residence. The agent states that he has not seen these buildings but has been informed that they are in good condition and would be suitable for the purpose. He also states that they can be taken down without much damage to the material and that the Indians will do all the work themselves in connection with the removing and rebuilding.

The school at this point was burned on May 15th, 1917, and classes have been conducted since that time in the church building which has been used as a school room and teacher's residence for which a rental of $50.00 per annum is paid.

The summer of last year tenders were called for the erection of a log building and only one tender was received which was considered too high. The amount of the tender was $6,058.00. It was then decided, as there was an abundance of logs on the reserve, to have the work done by Indian labour under the oversight of competent foreman. As the foreman engaged took ill it was considered that it would be too late in the season to begin the work and the agent was informed that it was to be postponed until the following spring (1920).

The Indians of this band have to their credit in Capital Account $62,438.00, and the entire cost, if the two buildings mentioned above are purchased, removed and fitted up as a school and residence, could be paid from the capital at the credit of the band.

I would suggest that Agent Lewis be instructed to inspect the buildings and if he considers that they would be suitable for the purpose and can be removed, that he be
authorized to have the Indians proceed with the work and also if he considers that the price asked for, namely, $930.00 is reasonable, that the cost of the purchase be paid from the capital funds of the band.

In view of the communication from the principal men of the band authorizing the expenditure it would not be, I think, necessary to receive a resolution from the Band-in-Council to provide the funds required. It would, no doubt, be a great deal cheaper to purchase these buildings and have them removed than to erect a new school building.

I shall be pleased if you will inform me as to what reply to make to the above request.

In reply to Official Letter No.19-8-5 of the 7th ultimo, in regard to the question of purchase of two buildings at the Gold Mine near Whitefish Lake Reserve for use as school and teacher's residence at Whitefish Lake, I have the honor to report that I inspected these buildings on the 31st ultimo, and found one of the buildings, which is built of logs, not suitable for a teacher's residence, as the logs are found pine with the bark on them and are beginning to decay. The cost of moving these logs would be above their value.

With regard to the other building which is a frame cottage of one story ready cut type. Inside dimensions are length 31 feet, width 23 feet, height of ceiling 10 feet; outside of building is finished with clapboards covered layer of mineral-hair felt fastened to half inch boards; roof is covered with two layers of heavy tar paper and hair felt in between. Interior is finished with beaver board and hardwood floors throughout; all windows and doors are finished with white enamel. There are six windows 33 inches by 63 inches, upper and lower sashes each containing one sheet of glass, and storm shades are complete for all windows. Entrance door is 2 feet 10 inches by 6 feet 10 inches and contains one sheet of glass 35 inches by 32½ inches.

This building is situated at the present time seven miles from Whitefish Lake Indian Village, and I consider it suitable for a school if moved to the Village, but the Indians cannot move it free of charge as they cannot afford to work for nothing and let their families suffer. I consider that it will cost at least $600.00 to have the building moved, and rebuilt, so the Indians will have to get some wages in order to board themselves while working, and the cost of team work moving the material, and also nails and new roofing paper will have to be purchased.

The owner, Mr. Rowley, asks $700.00 for the building it stands at the Gold Mine, which is quite reasonable for a building of its appearance, and the Indians claim that they can take it down, move it to the village at Whitefish Lake and re-erect it in two weeks time.

As these will have to be a school erected at Whitefish Lake and the cost of erecting a modern school in such backward place will be very high, therefore, I would recommend the building in question be purchased and have the Indians move to the Village.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the purchase of the buildings at the gold mine near Whitefish Lake Reserve for use as a school and teacher's residence at Whitefish Lake.

In reply I beg to say that it is noted that one of these buildings, which is built of logs, would not be suitable for the purpose of a teacher's residence and the Department could not, therefore, consent to the purchase of this building.

With regard to the frame cottage, which it is proposed to use for school purposes, I have to request that you will be good enough to state how the Indians propose to move this building, also whether they have the equipment necessary and are competent to do the work of removing and fixing up this building. It is considered that it would be impracticable to put up such a classroom. It will be necessary to secure the Minister's consent for obtaining the funds required, which will be taken from the interest at the credit of the band, namely, $700.00 to purchase the building and also for the $400.00 estimated by you as being required for having the building removed and rebuilt and for any material required to fit up the building. You should state when the Indians propose to undertake this work and the probable length of time they would be in moving the building and having it fitted up for school purposes.

The Department is disposed on your recommendation to authorize the purchase of this building and its removal, but, before doing so, would like to have further information, as requested above.

You should state whether, if the work is gone on with, you would require an accountable cheque besides the amount to purchase the building, to pay the Indians while they are doing the work of moving and fitting it up, also whether the Indians would guarantee to have the building placed in a satisfactory condition for school purposes without further expense other than the equipment, such as desks, blackboards, etc. You should also state under whose supervision the work will be carried on, as it is thought that the Indians themselves would not be likely to carry out the work satisfactorily.

An early reply, giving full information, is requested.

Your obedient servant,

The Indians wish to do all the work themselves as they consider that they are capable of moving the building in question and rebuilding and placing it in a satisfactory condition for school purposes without further expense other than the equipment.

As the Indians are quite handy with carpenter tools and build all their own houses without any person to supervise the work, therefore, I imagine that they should be capable of moving this building and placing it in a fit condition for a school themselves. If there is a man taken in to supervise the work the cost will be much higher.

I might also state that Mr. Rowley, the owner of this building, is awaiting the department's decision in this matter, as he has a chance to dispose of the building to a party residing near Midway.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant furnishing a report regarding the frame cottage, which you recommend the purchase of to the Department to be used for school purposes at Whitefish Lake.

In reply I beg to say that, as you state the Indians are ready to start the work of taking this cottage down and moving it to Whitefish Lake and re-building it and that they are capable of doing the work, the approval of the Superintendent General has been given to purchase the building at the price of $700.00 and have it removed to Whitefish Lake and re-erected as a building for school purposes.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School, states that a woodshed is necessary in order to keep the wood dry in winter. He also states that he doubts if there is sufficient wood on hand to last the winter. I have to request that you will state whether you can arrange to have an inexpensive building suitable for the purpose of storing wood erected this fall; and, if so, the probable cost of the material and labour. You should also arrange to have an ample supply of firewood purchased and delivered at the school. This wood should be cut into proper stove lengths.

The Inspector also states that a pair of blankets, a bedspread and a coffee pot are required for the teacher's use. You may purchase and have delivered one pair of blankets, a bedspread and a coffee pot.

The Inspector further states that the stove is in urgent need of repairs. The ash pan cannot be closed properly. You should arrange to have any repairs required made to the stove, and you may purchase any new parts required for the purpose.

You should give all the above matters your prompt attention, in order that conditions will be made as comfortable as possible for the teacher, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the above supplies.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School, has again drawn attention to the need of a woodshed. In this connection I beg to refer you to your letter of November 4th, last, in which you stated that owing to the difficulty in obtaining material the building of this shed would be left over until the coming summer when the work could be done at a reasonable cost. You should make enquiry as to whether you can arrange to obtain the materials and have the work done. It is not intended that an expensive shed be erected, but it should be of a size suitable to meet the requirements, the walls rough boarded, with a sloping shingled roof, and the door should have a good strong fastening.

The Inspector also states that the roof leaks over the dining room. You should enquire into this, and state what repairs would be required. It might be advisable to have them carried out at the same time as the woodshed is being erected.

Ottawa, August 9th, 1927.

Sir,

With regard to a supply of water for the school, I have to report that there is not any well in connection with this school, and not even a well on the whole Reserve. If a well is drilled it will be costly as it will have to be lowered below the level of the lakes and when the water is taken from such a great depth it will be a question whether, or not, it will be fit for drinking.

In my opinion it would be wise for the Department to pay a certain amount each quarter to have water carried from the lake for use of the teacher rather than drill a well.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re - Attached Report,
Whitefish Lake School.

In reply to your letter of June 25th with reference to above, you will recall that this school house at Lake Penage was considered a temporary school and was built by the Indians with lumber given for the purpose by the A. H. Brunne Company, Timber operators on the Whitefish Lake Reserve.

The building is much in keeping with the other buildings on the mill site, built of rough lumber with heavy white paper on inside walls and a good spruce floor, tar paper on outside walls. The entrance is at the wrong end of building but a proper door and two additional windows would give the required light. The equipment, benches, blackboards, stove, etc., were moved from the old school at Naughton. My letter of February 27, 1945, re Post War Plans, will give you the estimate for completion of building.

It is correct that there is no teacher's residence and so far there has been no necessity for one since Mrs. Petchegoose and her predecessor, Mrs. Euphosee, own their own homes and reside with their husbands and children.

Concerning the inspector's report on the teacher, I believe it is exaggerated and I would suggest that, if possible, white teachers be employed. These Indian women are all married and raising families and the inspector might have added that their "timing is perfect" as I know that the addition to Mrs. Petchegoose's family is due in July.

The school yard is partly completed by draining and filling with saw dust and there are now making a baseball grounds. I recently purchased the land for the school house.
well and this will be installed immediately.

If the Department feels that this school should be completed this summer, I will make arrangements to do so.

J.A. Maclean,
Indian Agent.
On my last visit to Lake Penage, I was very pleased with the cooperation between whites and Indians. The swamp by the school has been drained and a playground and baseball field built on it; Indians and whites working together. There was a great deal of work attending to the enterprise as the trees had to be cut and stumped and quantities of filling were required. The A.R. Brome Company supplied the lumber, furnished the bull-dozer and trucks to haul gravel and saw dust for filling to make the task possible.

In the process of draining the swamp, they have built a well at the spring, also built a hemlock drain underground to carry the excess water to the lake. The pump for the well was purchased by the Department.

This is another example of what can be achieved with Indians if they are given an opportunity to mingle at work and school with whites. Five years ago this band was at a standstill, filthy and sick. Now with the heads of families earning a fair wage, they are content, properly fed and healthy.

J.A. Marleau,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM TO FILE:

WHITEFISH LAKE (R.C.) INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

I was only able to visit this school on a Sunday and therefore it was not in operation.

TEACHER

Mrs. Istahtegone has a first class certificate and has had 5 years' experience. She seems a bright and capable enough teacher and is definitely interested in her pupils. She has a large family herself and at times seems more interested in her family than in the school. She has made her classroom attractive and is quite keen to learn of new methods and on the whole would seem to be satisfactory. She lives with her husband in a small house near the school.

BUILDING

This is a temporary structure which is gradually being converted into a permanent one. It has now been covered with insul brick and is beginning to look attractive. The inside is covered with Ten Test and is given a coat of paint in order to help brighten the inside. Mr. Marleau is planning small teacher's quarters and cloak-room for the back of the building. As the structure has no basement or furnace it differs greatly from our standard plan. However, it will serve the needs of these Indians, particularly in view of the fact that the mill has now closed down. Therefore there is a possibility that some of these Indians or all of them may move away.

Bernard F. Henry
Supt. of Education

Sir:-

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 430214/I of the 2nd instant, and in reply I have the honor to report that the cause of the small attendance of the pupils at the Wikwemikong Day school at the time of Mr. Inspector Finne's inspection was that there are a number of the families moved away to the mill-towns for the fall season where they secure work loading lumber boats and work in the mills, also there were a number of measles cases on the reserve which has kept a number of pupils from school for some time, but the families are moving home now and the measles epidemic is about over and the attendance at this school will soon be up to the average.

I would not recommend the appointment of a truant officer, as it is hard to get an Indian to act in this capacity. I might say that during last year truant officers were appointed on the Sucker Creek and Shegianandah reserves which did not help matters any.

Dear Sir:

I am sending you the school reports on the Catholic Indian Schools of Whitefish Lake, West Bay, Buswah, South Bay, Kaboni, Wikwemikong.

Also enclosed you will find a report on the Indian children in attendance at the Little Current Separate School. Please take particular note of this as I feel that the school board concerned should be reimbursed. An early reply to this will favour. I trust you will look on it favourably.

Would you be good enough to give each report a close scrutiny for the following reasons?

South Bay has just been opened after some years being closed. Naturally there are things needed.

West Bay needs some very heavy articles.

Buswah school school can only be condemned as a school building. However if other school buildings were to be erected to meet the needs of other parts of this reserve I would suggest that this be left as it is and kept in repair until a new school could be built. When you contemplate this I would suggest that it be located somewhere east of the Buswah church on the Wikwemikong road. The present location is not at all central for the territory served.

Wikwemikong school serves a good number of children but it cannot serve all that it is supposed to do. Across the bay from this school is a group of children (30) who never can come due to the distance. North West of here about five miles and more at a place called Rock Village is another group unable to attend. I found this out on enquiry from the teacher as to the large number (150) on the reserve attending this school and the few in comparison that attend (57). I am a firm believer in the efficiency of the small rural school if properly staffed, and in its ability to serve the people. Can something be done to build small schools one at each of these places?

The school at Wikwemikong is closed. Some 10 children here are not at school. Kaboni is too far over five miles.

Now regarding Whitefish Lake school five miles from the C.P.R. Station at Naughton. This school is being held in the Indian church and the teachers rooms are in a lean to at the back. This is my first visit here. Last year I had very little time to spare. I will not say very much except that you know the situation well and no doubt agree that it is not suitable to hold school in the Indian church here. I urgently call this to your attention. When could the Department arrange to build?

I present the above to your favourable consideration.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Inspector of Separate Schools
Northern Ontario.

Now, to come to an altogether different subject! Owing to the fact that justice forces me to oppose the actual chiefs in what I wrote above, they did not speak to me of their idea of having here a third teacher. Dear Sirs,-

The following is the report of my work on this reserve for the past month.

If only they all would send their children to school. I see so many children of school age running around the roads during school hours.

On November 15th I visited the two school rooms here. I did not think it was a good idea to have two single desks close together as they have them. The primary teacher frequently complains of her pupils having sore throats. Dear Miss Bonnot:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the vacancy at Wikwemikong. We understood from previous correspondence received from Miss Fox and the Indian Agent that she would be unable to return to the school for a considerable period of time and we therefore felt it necessary to secure a teacher.

Before making any appointment, however, Mr. Phelan received a letter from Miss O'Driscoll, suggesting the name of Miss D'Amour. We waited until Wednesday, last, but no application was received from her and, as a matter of fact, we have not yet heard from her.

We did not wish the school to be without a teacher and therefore engaged the services of Miss Rita Chisholm, who holds Ontario qualifications, to take charge until June 30th, next. It was intended, when she was appointed the other day, to have both Miss Charlebois and herself leave here on the 20th instant; but Miss Charlebois is not well at present and we have therefore arranged for them to delay their departure until the 17th instant.

I wish to assure you that, in appointing Miss Chisholm, the Department was only acting in what was considered the best interest of all concerned, as I understand that your Order had not a teacher available. As pointed out above, her appointment is only until the end of the current academic year, as we could not secure her consent to go for a shorter time. It is impossible for us to cancel her appointment at present and I trust that, when you have given this letter your careful consideration, our action will meet with your concurrence. It is distinctly understood, of course, that for the new academic year, beginning September first, next, we will look to you to nominate a suitable teacher, or teachers, if you have two available, for this school.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

On the 23rd ultimo, I visited the Wikwemikong Indian Day School, which is at present conducted in the old building near the church. As far as I could learn from a brief visit, Miss Sadie Burke and Miss Agnes Manitowab - the latter an Indian girl - are doing very efficient work.

I visited the new building which was erected during the fall and early winter, and I believe it very suitable for our purposes. There is considerable still to be done, however, before school can be conducted there, as follows:

1. Well and water supply system.
2. Sewage disposal system.
3. Outdoor toilets for boys and girls.
4. Benches for Monday lunch.
5. Cupboards for children's dishes.
6. Woodshed.
7. Kitchen cupboards and tables.
8. Dry storeroom in the cellar.
9. Cupboards and bookcases in classrooms.
10. Levelling the grounds and fencing.
11. Chemical toilets for teachers.

The ladies of the Hardene Order, who are responsible for the teaching at this school, also requested that we provide a summer kitchen at the back. After the building is occupied, the need for this will be better determined. I believe the Department should seriously consider purchasing a few more feet at the back of the building, to take in a rather low spot there. This could
be fenced so that cattle would not get into it, and we should consider draining it. I looked at the contour of the land behind and I believe that the draining would be comparatively inexpensive. New desks are not required, as the ones now in use can be sanded and varnished and moved over.

To properly prepare the building and grounds for school purposes will require a considerable outlay and I propose to place an item in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year. Of course, there are no funds at the present time for the purpose, and, anyway, for some reason or other, the teachers are not in a hurry to move to their new quarters. They asked that the final work be postponed until next fall. Father Artus also requested that we postpone moving to the new building until 1928. In view of the fact that funds were not available to prepare the school for occupation, I informed them that we would consider their request.

In view of the whole situation, I wish to recommend that we prepare new school for occupation early in 1928 and that the classes and teachers move over as from September first of that year.

Russell T. Girrier

Your letter of the 29th ultimo has been brought to my attention. At the outset I may say that we do not appear to have had any report from the Indian Agent with reference to the matter to which you refer in the second paragraph of your letter.

While regretting that the conduct of the children after school hours is not all it might be at the same time I think that it is extremely difficult for you to take this into account when preparing the quarterly return. This is presumed to be a report on the children in attendance at school and includes their grading, the number of days they attend and their standing in the class. If this information is supplied on the return I think you are doing all that you are required to do.

Of course, if at any time you feel that moral conditions on the Reserve are not as good as they should be it is your privilege to either bring the matter to the attention of the Indian Agent or direct to the Department. In all such cases, of course, it is necessary for us to have complete facts such as names, places and a brief account, at least, of the occurrence which you think is undesirable.

With kind personal regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Catherine O'Driscoll,
Indian Day School,
Wikwemikong, Ont.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

WIKENMIKONG INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

This is now being operated as a three-room school. Two of the rooms are in the actual school building and one is about a mile away in the old church. The junior room is located in this latter building.

TEACHERS

(a) Sister Lalemant

This teacher is the Principal and has had 20 years' provincial experience. She holds a first class certificate. Her room tested quite well in the tests which I administered.

The lighting is fair and will be improved when the Dalec plant is installed. The classroom is attractive with posters, flowers, children's art work, etc. Unfortunately, there are very few boys in the upper grades but I hope that the present teachers can overcome this situation. This teacher's discipline is very good.

(b) Sister Laurentia

Sister Laurentia has a second class certificate and has had some 23 years' experience in Indian schools. She is doing very good work with these children and they have now become accustomed to having Sisters teaching them. Her classroom is bright and attractive with an abundance of plants, flowers, etc. These children should do well with the experienced teacher now.
NIKEMIKONG INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

(b) Sister Laurentia (cont'd.)

in charge and we should get a larger proportion of boys in the upper grades. The problem, however, is one again of language difficulty.- With the children speaking nothing but Indian, the moment they leave the classroom.

(c) Sister Alberta

This teacher has the primary room and I understand has done good work with them. She has no experience nor certificate other than a course which she took at the Mother House in North Bay.

TEACHERAGE

A good job was done on the kitchen and chapel. The school is 15 years old and the whole building is in good condition. The church building, used as a classroom, will suffice for a few years as it is light and airy. The main school is furnace-heated and is warm in the winter.

RECOMMENDATIONS

1. That Sister Laurent be up-graded to Principal Grade I.
2. That the senior room be moved to the old church and the junior room be transferred to the main building.
3. That we consider this school as one of those in which we will experiment with the pupils on the Vocabulary Speller.

Dear Mrs. Beacom:

I was away from Port Arthur, on this last trip, for only some eight days terminating today, and so am answering your letter of November in a little more speedily than usual. It is hoped that the unusually prompt reply won't give you a shock or anything like that.

The school at Wikwemikong is an Indian Lay school, operated by the Indian Affairs Branch of the Dominion Department of Mines and Resources.

Hitherto, when any teacher has applied to be permitted to do practice teaching in an Indian School I have always preferred their going to a regular Provincial school.

However, there are some special circumstances in this case. Miss Wikwemikong is an Indian maiden, and she will, in all probability, be teaching in an Indian school among her own people, since Indian Affairs is genuinely interested in helping along promising Indian pupils.

Moreover, Sister H. Lallamont, who is in charge of the Wikwemikong Indian Lay School has had over twenty years' experience in various provincial schools before taking over the Wikwemikong school in September, 1947. She has a Permanent First Class Certificate, with special certificates in Art, and in Art and Crafts. She is genuinely interested in Indian school work, (although she has not had much more than a year's experience at it), because, although she was principal of a Provincial school, she volunteered for Wikwemikong when it fell vacant.

Because of the special features of this case, I am prepared to recommend that Miss Wikwemikong be allowed to do her teaching at the Wikwemikong Indian Lay School. Special arrangements, I suppose, will have to be made with Indian Affairs for permission to use the Wikwemikong Indian Lay School for this purpose, but I have no doubt that it will be more than willingly granted. I am attaching a copy of a letter I have written to Indian Affairs at Ottawa in this connection. A reply will doubtless be reaching you in a short time.

Yours very sincerely,

W.J. Greening

It would save time if you sent the principal of the North Bay Normal School the necessary authority for him to use the Wikwemikong Indian Day School for Miss Pitawanakwat's work in Continuous Practice Teaching in Rural schools.

There is just the one point upon which I am not too certain as to your own views. You know the Wikwemikong situation pretty clearly, including the fact that it is a three-roomed school, a rather unusual school for neophyte Indian teachers to start in.

Such a teacher would more likely start in a one-roomed school, such as Rabbit Island, or Murray Hill Indian Day School, (if the latter school is yet in operation). Murray Hill Indian Day School is not so very far from the Wikwemikong Indian Day School and if Mrs. John Wabegijig, (Agnes Lantowabi), is in charge, she could give you many valuable "tips". As you may perhaps suspect, I have always been very fond of Agnes. She is one of the young ladies I think of first when thinking of what can be turned out from Indian schools.

It is something for you to think about, as I suppose Gertrude will be in one of your schools next September. Don't be afraid to tell Mr. Beacom just what you think. You will find him prepared "to lean over backwards" in grasping any opportunity to help any of his students.

Sir,

Referring to official letter of date 4th Instant informing me that the Department is in receipt of a letter from Miss Frawley, teacher at Wikwemikensing in which she states that she ordered school supplies in August last, also that she had not yet received the flannelette and other accessories to teach sewing which was authorized in July.

In reply to this I beg to report that in so far as her first complaint is concerned that this Office has no record of receiving any Requisition from Miss Frawley during the month of August or subsequent although she was furnished with the necessary blanks. In regard to her second complaint that she has not received the flannel-ette &c., I beg to say that this is a deliberate and uncalled for falsehood and I am very much surprised that she should make such a statement. She must have taken leave of her senses. The flannel-ette and all accessories authorized was forwarded to her on the 26th August and she receipted for same and forwarded receipt on the 27th August. I presume her Requisition for school supplies was made in her imagination if she has one, her memory must be failing, but, I would think that she would have at least a part of the flannel-ette to remind her that this had been supplied.

Mr. Pedley,

After taking the pupils to the Wikwemikong Industrial School I visited, as instructed, the Wikwemikongising and South Bay Day Schools, which are situated on the unceded portion of Manitoulin Island. The reports of the Separate School Inspector on the work at these two schools have always been most commendatory and, after personal visits, I feel that these reports are entirely correct.

I reached Wikwemikongising about 9.30 a.m., and found ten children present, nine of whom were girls. The girls were in the midst of a lesson in domestic science and there was just being removed from the oven in the teacher's residence a tempting looking batch of bread. Miss Frawley and her companion are certainly enthusiastic workers. The school-room and living quarters were clean and tidy. All the children in this school can knit and they are given sewing lessons in addition to the instruction in baking. Seven girls out of the nine are kept from Monday morning till Friday night in the old school building.
building. The Department now furnishes some supplies for a mid-day meal and the Indian parents are supposed to supply other provisions. Miss Frawley, however, states that they are somewhat remiss in their duty and it often falls upon her to provide from her slender means the funds for buying these provisions, as well as clothes occasionally. They were making some quilts for the beds which were furnished by the Department a few years ago and I would recommend that the Department furnish seven pairs of blankets and sufficient enamel to re-enamel their bedsteads and also linoleum for the dormitory room, which is about 14 feet by 15. It is in this room that they have their sewing lessons and it is very difficult for the teacher to keep the floor clean. The linoleum can be purchased at a reasonable price in Manitowaning. A teacher's chair is also needed.

Miss Leuch, teacher at the South Bay School, is most energetic. So far as the class-room work is concerned the standing at her school may be a little higher than at Miss Frawley's and she also is doing a great deal for the young Indians of the section in which she is working. There were sixteen children present on the afternoon of my visit. There is at present before you
for approval a letter authorizing the purchase of some furnishings for the school-room and teacher's quarters, etc., at this school. It is their intention to keep in residence during the winter some of the pupils living at a distance from the school.

I am sorry that these schools are so situated that they are seldom seen by anybody except the Indian Agent and the missionaries who visit the reserves, as either or both of them would be distinctly a credit to any white neighborhood, in respect to buildings, equipment and class-room work. In both these schools there are organs, for the purchase of which the Department was not asked to contribute and, taking everything into consideration, the Department should do what it can to make conditions comfortable for those who are making such a sacrifice for the Indian children. I may here mention that both Miss Frawley and Miss Leuch are the holders of teacher's certificates. At South Bay too there is a companion for the teacher, who assists in the domestic science work and in the care of the resident children. The Department does not allow any salary for these helpers. These are virtually improved day schools of the best type and for similar service in the west we are called upon to pay
wages to those who prepare the mid-day meals, etc.

I would, therefore, recommend that as a recognition of merit and to aid in the financing of their work, the salaries of these two teachers be increased from $400.00 to $450.00 per annum.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed, two statements re Witwenmitong's school, viz.: one, existing already but closed for a time (the village school); the other, to be built, they say, and opened in January 1916 (the Saboni settlement's school). Now, the Indians from the village ask if the department would consent to reopen their school, and promise to send their children regularly. None of them is anxious to see their children going to the new school in Saboni settlement. "It is too far," they say. In fact, the shortest distance for the nearest families would be 3½ miles, and the longest distance 6½ miles. In my opinion, the only way to solve the school's problem in this place, would be to have two schools in operation, on account of distances. Nothing, of course, could be done without the consent of the department; but should the department be willing to reopen again the village's school, it would facilitate immensely the problem of educating the Indian children of Witwenmitong.

Respectfully yours,
Ernest [signature]

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant in which you point out that even if a school is opened in the Kiboni settlement it will be too far away from the Indians living in Wikwemikong to allow the children there to attend and recommend that the school at Wikwemikong, where there is a building, should be re-opened at once.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to carry on either of these schools this winter. The Kiboni School building has not yet been started and it is not considered feasible to make a success of a school at Wikwemikong during the winter months owing to the distance that nearly all the pupils would have to go and the difficulty of obtaining a properly qualified teacher at this time of the year. I may say, however, that the educational needs of the children on this portion of the reserve will receive due consideration.

In the meantime, if any of the parents are as anxious as they appear to be to have their children educated, they might take advantage of the facilities offered at the Spanish River Industrial School, where there is room for more pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Ernest Comte, C.J.,

Ottawa, June 2nd, 1923.

Sir,

The Bureau School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kaboni Indian Day School, states that there are about 17 children of school age at Mikwemikong who are too far away to attend. He recommends that a bus service be arranged for after the summer holidays to take these children to and from their homes, which would be cheaper than re-opening the Mikwemikong school.

I shall be pleased if you will make inquiry regarding the situation mentioned by the Inspector. You should state the number of children of school age at Mikwemikong who do not attend school, and if you could give your views regarding the suggestion made regarding the establishment of such a bus service to carry these children to the Kaboni school. You should also state whether it would be possible to arrange with an Indian agency the necessary team and rig for the purpose, and the cost per month that would be charged for the service. The Inspector is of the opinion that, if a bus service is instituted for a period of, say, 6 months in each year, it would not cost more than approximately $40 per month.

You will be good enough to give this matter your consideration, and report your opinion to the Department, in order that, if it is decided to arrange for a bus service, the necessary steps can be taken to begin the work on or about the 1st of October next, or the 1st of September, if you think it should start from this earlier date. Such an arrangement, if carried out, might be the easiest solution of providing educational facilities for the children residing at Mikwemikong.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

It is noted that, owing to the large number of pupils attending, Miss Charlebois, the assistant teacher, finds it impossible to give both classes the required attention.

Rather than close the senior classroom, you should, if you can arrange to do so, engage the services of a substitute teacher until the Christmas holidays, by which time it is hoped Miss Fox will be able to resume duties. Miss Charlebois could take charge of the senior room and the substitute teacher the junior room. The question of salary to be allowed a substitute will be determined when we have particulars as to the name, qualifications, etc. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the best arrangement for carrying on the work until Miss Fox returns, and you should state, at an early date, the name, qualifications, etc., of the substitute teacher engaged. We note that you are of the opinion that a substitute teacher can be obtained locally.

You should ascertain from Miss Fox when she expects to be able to resume duties, and if her condition of health will not permit her to return after the Christmas holidays, the services of a qualified teacher could then be engaged.

Sir,

Referring to Official letters of date 1st Oct. last and 14th Instant in regard to the need of a new school building at Wikwemikongising.

I have the honor to report that the school house now occupied is without a doubt very small and a larger and better lighted and ventilated building would be desirable.

With regard to the location, I do not see that it could be improved on to a very great extent as the children who come from a distance are pretty well scattered and a location that would be favourable to some would be detrimental to others; besides, if a new building were erected and the location changed it would interfere with the teacher's quarters which at the present time are attached to the school.

If a new building is erected the old school could be utilized as a part of the teacher's residence and would give them ample room.

If funds are available I would be pleased to recommend that a new school house be erected the coming spring.

Your obedient servant,

Agreement made in duplicate the seventh day of June—— A.D. 1909.

Between His Majesty King Edward the Seventh, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And Robert Caldwell Outhrie of the village of Manitouwining District of Algoma, E.R. Province—Ontario,

(hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame school house erected on stone foundation at Fekwamikong-sing, Manitoulin Island Ont., including all trades complete according to plans and specifications prepared for the same by the Department of Indian Affairs being No L93, and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the first day of October A.D. 1909.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of one thousand nine hundred and fifty dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees—

14th Sept., 1909

Referring to previous correspondence in regard to the new school building at Wikwemikong.

I have the honor to report that the contractor Mr. R. C. Guthrie has the new school building well under way and expects to have it completed by the 1st Prem.

The plasterers are now at work and the building has had one coat of paint outside.

I beg to call your attention to the fact that no provision was made for either closets or wood shed for the new school and as it is quite a little distance from the old buildings it will be absolutely necessary that suitable closets and shed be provided. The old closets are not worth moving and in any event one of them will be required where it is for use with the teachers dwelling.

I beg to enclose herewith a requisition for school material for the Wikwemikong school among other things requisitioned for is a stove; the stove that I took from the old Buzwah school could be sent over to them and would save buying one.

Will you be good enough to advise me as to what it is to be done in regard to closets and shed in order that I may, if you conclude to build them, get prices from Mr. Guthrie while he is on the ground.

Your obedient servant,

27th Sept. 1909

Sir,

Referring to your letter of date 23rd Instant with regard to the offer of Mr Guthrie to erect two closets and a woodshed in accordance with plans sent me for the sum of $225.00.

I have the honor to report having interviewed Mr Guthrie and as per your instructions asked him to reconsider his offer. He now offers to do the work for $180.00 providing his offer is accepted at once as he will be through with the school building in this week. He informs me that it is a very expensive place to build at owing to the distance the material has to be conveyed and also the fact that all materials for the construction of the buildings has to be freighted from either Owen Sound or Collingwood to Manitowaning and then teamed to the reserve. This may seem strange to you, but, I can assure you that it is a fact nevertheless. Nearly all the building material for use in the construction of buildings in this place is imported from either of the above places as it is impossible to get good dry material anywhere nearer. If you wish Mr Guthrie to do this work I wish you would wire your decision as soon as you receive this in order that he may make arrangements to complete the work at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary

Sir,

Referring to Official letter of date last inst confirming telegram of even date accepting the offer of Mr Guthrie for the erection of a wood shed and two closets in connection with the Wikwemikongising Indian school.

I have the honor to report that the contents of your letter have been carefully noted and can assure you that the instructions contained therein will be carried out to the letter. I have made several inspections of the school building and it is about completed and it certainly is a credit to the Department and contractor. The chimney on the teacher's residence requires attention and also the shed. The chimney requires re-pointing and a few new bricks, the shed requires a new covering on the roof as it leaks very badly. A covering of Paroid roofing would be the best thing for this.

In regard to the suggestion that quarters be provided for some of the children I bet to say that the teacher and her companion at this school have kept from five to eight boarders, children from a distance, the old school building is intended

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
to be used as a dormitory for these as the old school building and the teachers quarters adjoin.

Heretofore they have been very much cramped for room but now it is hoped they will have ample accommodation for the pupils they keep. These pupils have been kept by the Mission and no pay asked for from the Department. It will be necessary that a little furnishing be supplied to equip the sleeping apartment which will not amount to very much. I will find out exactly what is needed the next time I visit Wikwemikong and report as to the cost of same.

The teacher requires a single iron bed with spring and mattress as they have only one bed now, for the teacher and her companion, this was asked for on requisition referred to by you in your letter of 20th Ult. The cost of a new bedstead, spring and mattress will be about $9.00. The teacher and her companion deserve every consideration possible as they take great interest in the education of the children taking into consideration that they are doing it purely for charity's sake. They should at least be allowed the smaller comforts asked for in the way of sleeping accommodation.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent.

Sir,

Referring to official letter of date 26th Ult asking me to report on what action has been taken in regard to the purchase of a new stove for the Wikwemikong school.

I have the honor to report that immediately on receipt of your letter of October 24th last in which you authorized me to purchase a stove for this school I ordered one from the local dealer in Manitowaning. He did not have a suitable stove in stock at the time but assured me that he had one ordered, showed me the cut of it in a stove catalogue, and I told him I would take it on its arrival. I inquired for it several times but each time was informed that it was on the way but owing to the heavy freight traffic at that season of the year it would be late in arriving. As the condition of the roads did not warrant me in taking the stove over during the early part of December I did not go to see about it until the 15th Ult when I went to the store to take delivery of the stove and take it over to the school and have it set up, when to my extreme surprise Mr. Stove Dealer informed that his clerk had sold the stove and he had not another suitable engin stock. This is how I was humbugged in not having it in place. The roads since then have been almost impassible and I was unable, until today, to get another stove from outside dealers for the school. I have one here now and will

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
have it placed in position at the earliest possible moment. I got it from a Little Current dealer and it will fill the bill to the letter.

Regretting the delay in this which I can assure you was quite unavoidable on my part

Your obedient servant

Sir:

Referring to official letter under date 24th October last in regard to the jacketing of the stove at Wikwemikongising school.

I have the honor to report that I have just received a communication from Mr. Michael O'Brien, Separate school Inspector, Peterborough, enclosing me a plan for jacketing the stove which appears to be very much more simple than the one sent by the Department. The Inspector states that the system as suggested by him is the best for heating and ventilation for country schools. I am of the opinion that this could be done as suggested by the Inspector by an Indian tinker who does odd jobs of tinkering around Manitowaning if he the work was under supervision while being done. If the Department wishes I will have him undertake the work, but I cannot give an estimate as to what it will cost as he will have to make the jacket and fit it to the stove at Wikwemikongising. The Inspector will no doubt give you details as to the system he suggests.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, January 24, 1912.

Sir,

Mr. O. L. D. Sims, Indian Agent, Manitowaning, reports that you supplied him with a plan for a jacketed stove, which appears to him to be preferable to the one sent by the Department.

I would ask you to be good enough to let the Department have details and drawings of this plan, if possible.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Michael O'Brien, Esq.,
Separate School Inspector,
Peterborough, Ont.
Material: salvaged wire - stock size sheets will do, although it would be better to have the other side of the floor covered in the same.

Shape: make a plan of a square top, sloping at the top before sloping to add something to its appearance.

Construction: put together with small bolts rather than nails, so that it may be easily pulled apart when down.

Electric: let jack be set on floor all around cold air register on floor, but an ordinary box stove back there in the corner, in front of jacket, and which will give some heat within a radius of about 15 feet. Jack should be set in the corner, but the opening in the wall behind it should be large enough to allow for a chimney pipe. Jack should be set in the corner of the floor and stove. The opening in the wall behind it should be cut to fit either the stove or the jack. There should also be an opening of about diameter circular at back of stove jacklet for the opening to the cold air off floor in the chimney, and through which the air from the fire will be accessible. This opening should be covered with a cover.

Notes: the jack should be fitted air register from the top, and there must be a point of the jack to the end, which is made of pipe and wood inside and outside, and should be a wooden floor. It can be placed in the house, and kept in the air register, which could be closed at night and opened during the day.
Dear Sir,

They tell me that the government has approved the purchase of a new schoolhouse and I am pleased to hear of this. I visited the district last fall and found that a new school had been recently built in the area. It was a very satisfactory arrangement for the children but I did not have the opportunity to see it.

I was sorry to learn that something had been done for the Indians, as both Chiefs and Councils were present there last winter. I know that they are still interested in their own affairs and I believe that the new school will be a great benefit to them.

Yours respectfully,

Michael O'Brien

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant in reference to the purchase of prizes for the South Bay School.

In reply I beg to say that in official letter of April 21st, last, the intention of the Department was that $12.50 should be the total expenditure at both schools for the year, or $6.25 for each school. The Rev. Father Papineau, who was informed of the grant, has evidently misunderstood the Department's letter and told the teachers that the grant would be $6.25 for each quarter.

The amount, $6.25, for the year may be a little small and the Department has decided to increase it to $10.00, or $2.50 per quarter for each of the two schools. You will be good enough to advise the teachers accordingly, so that they will not make purchase for the current quarter over that amount. Sir:-

I have the honor to report that the outside doors at the Wikwemikongising school have been a source of trouble since the first. They open out and are of such a size that when the wind blows it is impossible to hold them from flying around and breaking.

The last time I was at the school I found that one of the doors had come to grief in this way; it is split almost beyond repair.

The only remedy for this will be to have the doors taken off and made to open; in otherwise they are liable to be blown from their fastenings at any time.

I would most respectfully recommend that authority be given to send over a carpenter and have him repair the broken door and hang it on the inside and also remove the other outside door and hang it to open inwards also.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

The industrial school at Wikwemikong has been closed and moved to Spanish River. As there are a large number of children living in the village of Wikwemikong for whom a school should be provided, the Department intends to continue the day school there, which was formerly held in the industrial school building. The Department has been in communication with Mr. Agent McLeod who states that the Rev. Father Desautels, who is acting for the church, demands a rent of $20.00 a month for the use of the building and that the church authorities insist that an agreement should be made between them and the Department before the Department takes possession of the building. They are either willing to rent or sell. The building needs repairs and refurnishing, as they were allowed to remove the desks to Spanish River.

After careful examination of the old records I do not see that the church has any title to the property under which they could claim rent. They have been using a certain
certain portion of the land in the village for mission and school purposes, but, as they have given up the school, I consider that the building used for that purpose reverts to the band. Father Desautels claims that the school and dependants are built on land ceded by the Indians for the use of the Missionaries. I think that any concession made years ago to the missionaries was on condition that they should maintain a mission and school. As the school has been abandoned they lose any claim they ever had to the property.

The school is now closed awaiting settlement. The teacher is under salary and school material and supplies will have to be furnished before it can be opened. I think it well, as I am going to Spanish River and Sault Ste. Marie, to interview Father Desautels and find out on what he bases his claim for compensation for the use of the building. It would not be well for the Department to enter into an agreement recognizing their title to the property, as it has never been surrendered and they have simply been granted use for certain purposes. There is no doubt that the Department has a perfect right to take possession of the building, as it has contributed $8,000.00, as shown by the papers on file, towards
towards its erection and it is built on unsurrendered land. I consider that Father Desautels is endeavouring to obtain recognition of their claim to the land, which does not exist. The opening of the school in this building would not interfere with any valid claim the church might have for compensation, but until they can show that they have such claim there is no reason why they should be allowed to virtually close the school.

May 10, 1921. 430214-6

Outbuildings need urgent attention. Proper building should be built and whitewashed so that these teachers can take care of them. They are in such dirty condition now that no one feels like going near them. Somebody did come but all they did was fix the doors last June.

The yard needs some attention for in spring and fall it is so muddy that the 100 children must stay in. All that is necessary is to use a plow and make a ditch or two.

J. K. Bennett,

[Stamp]
OTTAWA, May 28th, 1921.

Sir,

Mr. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School, states that the out buildings need urgent attention. He recommends that new closets be built, and white washed, so that the teachers can take care of them. He states that the ones in use at present are in a very dirty condition.

The Inspector also states that the school yard needs some attention, as in the Spring and Fall it is so muddy that the children must stay in the school. He states that all that is necessary is to use a plough and make a ditch or two, which would be sufficient to drain the yard.

I have to request that you will take immediate steps to have the out buildings cleaned and put in good condition. You should arrange, if possible, with a competent Indian to do this work. I should also be pleased if you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having two closets erected, with screens and fences separating each.

You should also furnish an estimate of the cost of having the yard put in good condition, and properly drained. It is considered that if the Inspector's suggestion is carried out that this should not cost very much.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mclean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that the lower floor in the North East side of the Wikwemikong School has dropped down and is in very bad condition. On examining closely the floor I found that it is nailed to planks 2x8 inches which are placed on sills around the wall, and all these have decayed and let the floor down. New timber will have to be put in and part of the floor replaced with new lumber. The roof has been leaking and requires fixing also the windows are in bad condition as the old frames are so old and decayed that they will not hold the putty.

With regard to the above I estimate that it will cost approximately $150.00 to have the repairs made in order that the building may be made comfortable for the winter.

I have started two men to repair the floor as it is necessary that it should be repaired at once in order that no accident may happen to any of the school children.

I might say for the information of the Department that this building is so old, extensive and poorly constructed that it will always be very expensive to keep it in repair.

Referring to the third paragraph of Official Letter No. 19-6-5 of the 29th ultimo in regard to the question of having a well drilled at the Wikemikong School in order to obtain a supply of water for the school, I have the honour to report that I have made an effort to procure the above well but not having this well drilled and a pump installed, but find that there are three drilling machines owned in this village and at the present time all are busy working on other parts of this district, one is working at Gore Bay, one at Little Current and the other is at Providence Bay.

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a voucher in my favour amounting to $23.30 for payments made by me to the different Indians in connection with certain urgent repairs being made at the Wikwemikong School before the re-opening after the mid-summer holidays.

With regard to the repairs being made to the closets, I have the honour to report that during the holidays one evening after a rain storm a hurricane passed through the lower portion of Wikwemikong Village where the school is situated, upsetting two closets which did them much damage, and also some of the Indian homes were badly shaken, but nobody was hurt. I had an Indian build a solid foundation for each closet and place them thereon, and made the necessary repairs that were required.

On account of the school being closed during July and August there was not any water taken out of the well which caused it to be unfit for use; therefore, I had to authorize Mr. Atchitawine to clean the well out and pump the water all out several times before the teachers and pupils were allowed to use it.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School, draws attention to the condition of the outside toilets. He states that the old ones should be removed, as they are an eyesore, and give a bad example to the children. He also states that more toilet accommodation is required. Kindly furnish a report regarding this matter, together with your views as to what you would suggest be done to make proper arrangements for the purpose.

The Inspector makes the following reference in his report to the fuel supplied:

"Usual supply of wood was not sent to this school during the winter for next winter's use. I hope that this does not mean that this school will have to use green wood next winter."

As you have already been requested in another communication, you will be good enough to see that arrangements are made to obtain the supply of wood required for next winter's use at all the day schools in your Agency.

Kindly state whether there is a flag pole at this school, as the Inspector recommends that a flag be supplied.

Sir:

In regard to Official Letter No. 19-6-5 of the 2nd instant, in connection with the report of the Separate School Inspector in regard to the toilet accommodation, supply of fuel and a flag pole at the Wikwemikong School, I have the honour to report that at the present time there are fourteen closets in use at this school, without the old buildings that the Inspector recommends should be removed, and I always considered that this school was very well supplied with toilet accommodation. I might say that there are only two large closets in use for the accommodation of the boys, as the others are in use by the girls and the school staff, and it may be that it is more toilet accommodation for the boys that the Inspector has reference to.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, regarding the toilet accommodation at the Wikwemikong Indian Day school.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that it would be advisable to have the old toilet buildings, referred to by the Inspector, removed and the ground on which they stand filled in and properly levelled. If you consider that this would improve the conditions complained of by the Inspector you may arrange to have the work done. Regarding additional toilet accommodation for the boys, it might be possible to arrange for more space by an addition to the present building. The material in the old building could be utilized for the purpose. We shall be pleased to hear from you, further, as to what you would recommend having done in this matter also the probable cost of providing more accommodation for the boys.

Regarding the erection of a flag pole, it is considered that the Indians should provide a suitable pole and have it erected. The Department will supply the necessary guy wires, rope and pulley. If the Indians will undertake the work, you may purchase the wire, rope and pulley. The Department will furnish a flag when the pole has been put up. If the Indians will not undertake the work of furnishing and putting up the pole, without cost to the Department, the supplying of a flag pole will have to remain in abeyance for the present.

Your obedient servant,
