Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., with reference to the provision of more toilet accommodation for the boys' at the Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have an addition erected to the present building. You should purchase and have delivered the material required, and the work should be done by day labour. You should see that the additional accommodation is of a type that will be satisfactory for the purpose. The Department will leave the erection of this addition in your hands, to make the best arrangements possible for the increased requirements. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers covering the cost of the material supplied, and for the labour, should be forwarded. This work should be proceeded with and completed before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays. We note that you estimate the cost to be approximately $50, and it should be kept within that figure, if possible.

We also note that the old toilet building is being removed, and the ground levelled, also that none of the material can be utilised for the purposes of erecting the new addition.

We further notice that the Indians will furnish a flag pole, without cost to the Department. It is presumed that this is for the pole and the work of putting up the same. If the Indians do not buy, by the wire, rope and pulley, you may purchase the same, as instructed in official letter of June 23rd, last. When the pole has been put up, you should requisition for a flag of the size required—either a 6' or a 9' being the standard size.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, regarding the renovating required to the classroom and hall of the Nekemkong Indian Day School, and the cost of the material and labour in carrying out this work.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of having the classroom and hall thoroughly cleaned and any necessary sanding and painting required carried out. You should arrange for the purchase of all materials required, and the work should be done by day labour under the charge of a competent foreman. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept showing the time they were employed, and the wages paid. In the purchase of any material, competitive prices should if possible be obtained, and the purchase made from the firm quoting the lowest price. You must have the material purchased and the labour arranged for in order that the work can commence as early as possible during the ensuing summer holidays. The total cost of the material and labour should not exceed your estimate of approximately $100, and the Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that the work is satisfactorily done at the lowest possible expense. Sir:

Referring to Official Letter No.19-6-5 of the 25th ultimo, regarding the Separate School Inspector's report of his recent inspection of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School, stating that the blackboards in the Junior Room are too high for the young children, and that more blackboard space is required, I have the honour to report that the blackboards are rather high for the small children and a small platform in front of them is under construction. I might say that these blackboards were always too high for the small children, but movable steps in front of them were not used until this year. The teacher in charge of the classroom at the present time does not approve of the steps and it is her request to either lower the blackboards or build a small platform in front of them.

On account of the blackboards being used to a great extent in teaching the small children more space is required, the dimensions required being plate board 4 feet by 6 feet, and to extend the one in the room at the present time which is plate, 3½ feet by 7 feet.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your report for the current month on the Wikwemikong Indian Day School, in which you recommend that casing be placed around the stove in order to make the pupils who have to sit close thereto more comfortable, I beg to say it is considered that if this casing were put up it would prevent the heat from radiating throughout the classroom. Sir:

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Wikwemikong School.

September 17, 1925.

The school bell cannot be heard in the village. These people have no clocks, naturally do not come on time. The present bell was never intended as a school bell. It is a yard one only. It will aid discipline and punctuality if you provide a bell large enough to be heard in the village.

Something must be done regarding the toilets. The girls' toilets are close to school and high off the ground and every girl entering them is seen by the boys and everyone on the playground. They are old.

The boys need a screen across and should be made individual toilets for the sake of morals. Besides a few wooden or zinc urinals should be made as the seats are continually wet. It is dangerous to health. The seats are also too high.

Can you furnish the senior room with desks? There are 24 single there now and it would aid much in discipline, order and appearance if you provided 12 more single with 4 backs and 4 fronts. As it is it is difficult to get around as aisles are too narrow and doubles are in the road. Besides the single have to be put alongside each other destroying their usefulness.

The teachers have no place to keep their supplies from mice. The cellar is cool but a concrete room 12' x 15' wo would be necessary to arrange in it. Can it be done?

A buffet (cheap) for dishes and linen would be welcomed. There is no furniture except six ordinary chairs, two beds and Coleman lamp.

J. M. Bennett, INSP.

Referring to Official Letter No. 13-C-5A
of September 20th last, relating to the report
of the Separate School Inspector on the toilets
at the Wikwemikong School, I have the honour to
report that I was of the opinion that the toilet
accommodation at this school was pretty fair and
almost equal to the closest accommodation in any
of the neighbouring rural White schools.

The girls' toilets consist of twelve individual
toilets erected at the end of the woodshed on the
east side of the playground. They are somewhat high
off the ground and have been in use for a number of
years, but with only little repairs and a screen
erected along in front of them should put them in
a satisfactory condition.

The boys' consist of three different buildings,
each having a double toilet. They are all new buildings
having a stone foundation under each and are in first
class condition. Before the school re-opened after the
holidays these buildings were thoroughly cleaned and
scrubbed and put in a state of good repair. It might
be well to have a screen erected in front of these
buildings, but I cannot see why individual toilets
should be made as they consist of three separate
buildings at the present time.

I would recommend that a screen be erected in front
of both the girls' and boys' toilets, and the seats
lowered so those that are too high, the cost of the
sand will be considerable and they cover a lot of space
and will require considerable lumber to build the screens,
I would estimate that the cost of the material and labour

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that the repairs have been in operation here since last week, and the able carpenter that was hired is giving great satisfaction.

We are just having the double compartments divided, and suitable platforms put in front of the seats, because to lower the seats, the foundation would have to be cut down etc., and this would have incurred greater expenses; so I suggested to have the platforms built instead.

Mr. Agent Lewis had consulted last December to have urinals installed in the boys' toilets, but in his last visit here, he mentioned that he would have new toilets built for the girls in the spring, so I suggested to let the question of urinals go for now, and that when the new toilets were being erected for the girls, the present ones could be moved to the west end of the boys' toilets, because they are only the old urinal stables that were in use for the boys when the boarding school was here.
This would prevent any undue expenditure.

Unions in boys' tents are most essential, because it is impossible, no matter how hard we try in other ways, to keep the boys truthful and in a sanitary condition.

Now, and I refrain from disclosing to you, the terrible condition the boys' tents always was in at this school, and when I made this remark to my principal, two years ago, she informed me, that she had referred the matter again and again to the superintendent, but had received no assistance from him in the matter.

Last September, when I came here as principal, that was the first thing I said before him, but it was all in vain.

Losing all confidence in him, I applied to the Board, and when the repairs did begin here the last week of December, I laid all my plans before Mr. Lewis on several occasions, but he did not heed them, except in the urinals.

The present fires' backs have no seats—All the fires have to sit on is the thickness of an inch board.

It was when I suggested having seats put in them that Mr. Lewis mentioned the erection of new ones.

I admit there are anything but what they should be for girls; however, I am willing to put up with them.
to keep down expenses.

What I have just described to you in this letter is the deplorable state of the toilet accommodation that has always existed in the Shuswap Indian day school.

I am not writing to complain of Mr. Lewis, but simply to inform you of the state of affairs here. Surely this will be satisfactory to you and thanking you for your kind assistance in the past.

I am

Your respectfully yours,

Sir—

In reply to Official Letter No. 19-8-5 of
the 28th of June, last, relating to the question
of providing satisfactory toilet accommodation
for the girls at Wikwemikong School, and also
the question of a water supply for the school
and teacher's residence, I have the honour to
report to the effect that as the toilets in use
by the girls are not satisfactory to the teachers
new buildings will have to be erected as it will
cost more to remove the old buildings than to
erect new ones. The old buildings have been in
use for a great number of years and the material
of which they are constructed is of very little
value. In order to erect a suitable building
with five different compartments the cost of the
same will be approximately $250. If there is to
be a change in the toilet accommodation for the
girls I would recommend a new building be erected.

The only means of procuring a water supply for
this school is to have a well installed and if this
means is carried out it will have to be drilled quite
deep in order to get below the surface water. At the
present time there is a well at the school equipped
with a new pump, but the water is not fit for drink-
ing purposes. Judging from the location where the school
is situated the prospects of obtaining a supply of
good water is not very bright but it can be given a
test and if it may prove a success, to have a drilling
outfit moved to Wikwemikong and have this work carried
out I estimate it will cost at least $300.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, July 26th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant relative to the providing of toilet accommodation for the girls at the Indian Industrial School, and give an estimate of the cost of erecting a new building with 5 different compartments.

In this connection it is noted that it would cost more to remodel the present closets than to erect a new one. It is considered, however, that if a building having 3 compartments were erected it would provide ample accommodation, and I have to request that you will ask for prices for the erection of a building for toilet purposes having 3 compartments only. Any material in the old building which would be of use might be used in the construction of the new toilets for the girls. Kindly reply giving the information asked for as to the cost involved as soon as possible.

Relative to the deepening of the present well, I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to incur the expenditure required in having a drilling outfit drill the present well to a greater depth, so it is very doubtful if a good supply of water could be obtained. The present arrangement for the providing of water for the use of the school will have to be continued.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, August 5th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of erecting a suitable toilet with three compartments for the girls at the Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this toilet erected by day labour under the charge of a competent foreman. You should arrange for the purchase, after obtaining competitive prices if possible, of all material required. Proper time sheets should be kept for the labour employed, and certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the cost of the material. Any material of value in the old building should be utilized as far as possible in the erection of the new toilet. This work should be carried out as cheaply as possible, and it is hoped that it will cost less than your estimate of approximately $175.00.

Please arrange to have this work started at an early date, as it is hoped to have it ready when the school reopens after the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. J. MacKenzie,
Acting Aest. Deputy and Secretary.
